They then attempted to fire the further extremity, but the volunteers at my call rushed forward in the face of their fire and saved it. The bridge from the island to the main shore we could not save.
It is of small moment, the length being only about 450 feet.
The prisoners taken report that five regiments of infantry and 1,800 cavalry were stationed at the bridge.
This campaign is ended, and I now occupy Huntsville in perfect security, while in all of Alabama, north of the Tennessee river, there floats no flag but that of the Union.

div4.head: From Fort weight--Commodore Foots' S operations.
div4.p: --There has been no change in the outward appearance of things here for the last two days, but certain indications now point to a speedy termination of our protracted siege, but I am not at liberty to say how soon.

A deserter to day from the rebel fleet says that the vessel to which he was attached has been employed for nearly a week past in cruising between Memphis and this point in search of cotton, and that every lot discovered had been burnt.
The lots varied from five to sixty bales, and the aggregate destroyed is several thousand bales.

The rebel gunboat fleet from New Orleans has arrived off Fort Wright and joined Hollins's fleet.
They have now a sufficiently strong naval force to make a show of resistance.

div4.head: The War in Arkansas.
div4.p:
--On the 24th ult. the Federal cavalry from this place destroyed an extensive saltpetre manufacturing establishment near Yellville, Arkansas, and burned the buildings.
Lieutenant Kickok, of the 4th Iowa Cavalry, was killed in a skirmish with the rebels.
A large quantity of supplies, hid for rebel use, with deserters and jayhawkers, hiding in the mountains, have been captured by Gen. Curtle's command.

div4.head: General Wool and the Wooly Heads.
div4.opener: Fortress Monroe, May 1. To Hon. Edwin M. Stanton, Secretary of War:
div4.p:
I have just received a dispatch from Brig. Gen. Mansfield to the effect that five negroes have arrived from Portsmouth.
The contrabands report that Fort Macon was taken on Friday last.
Eighteen rebels were killed and twenty-seven wounded.
General Beauregard had evacuated Corinth and fallen back to Memphis.
It is reported that Commodore Tatuall and the principal officers of the Merrimac have resigned.

The Merrimac lies off the Marine Hospital, at Craney Island, fast to the buoy.
She now mounts twelve guns.
There are no other steamers there.

div4.head: The siege of Yorktown.
div4.p:
The papers bring nothing new respecting affairs about Yorktown, though we find several letters from that neighborhood, under dates of April 28 and 30, containing the usual amount of romance and bombast.
We copy one or two paragraphs:

Within the last two or three days a brass band has been heard every morning and evening playing lively airs in Yorktown.
The yellow flag, which is the token for a hospital, now flies from the roof of nearly every house there; but one rag, known as the rebel ensign, floats to day over their works there.

This morning, about 9 o'clock, a popular brigade advanced beyond our rifle pits, the enemy appearing in force below the "dam." This brigade was sent out to watch their movements.
About 10 o'clock heavy musketry firing commenced and lasted about one hour.

About 11 o'clock the enemy sent up their miserably constructed and ill shaped balloon.
It was up about one minute, and down quick.
About ten minutes after it again appeared, staying up an minute.
The shape of this balloon is not unlike to two Sibley tents sewed together at the butts, being pointed at each end. It is like everything else manufactured at the South in its infancy.

The negro sharp-shooters were again in their position among the enemy.
Our soldiers dislike very much to be shot by negro soldiers.
When a negro is knocked over our men cry out "Set up another nigger."

After considerable further indulgence of frenzy, the writer gives the names of several Yanks who were killed or wounded in the skirmish on this occasion, from which it would appear that they had the worst of it. The letter concludes:

The object of this reconnaissance was for the purpose of destroying a lot of low bushes and brush, as the enemy had been in the habit of crawling up on their hands and knees and popping off our pickets.
The expedition was successful.
The brush and trees were removed, and now our pickets watch without fear or favor.
A Lieutenant of artillery, belonging to a Rhode Island battery, was badly wounded this morning.

The report of Major Cassady's return, wounded, was not true.
He is yet with the enemy.
He was formerly one of the editors of the Albany Argus and Atlas.
It looks very black on the part of both the Major and Colonel Crocker.
Their friends are in hopes that it will turn out all right yet.

div4.head: Burnside's Plans.
div4.p: A Baltimore letter to the Philadelphia Inquirer contains the following:

q.p:
A lady in this city, who has a husband in Burnside's army, is said to have received a dispatch or letter from him, which states that General Burnside had, or was about giving notice to the citizens of Norfolk and Portsmouth, that he proposed moving upon these cities in a given time, requesting them to surrender or prepare for the worst.
I give you, this as it comes to me through an intelligent channel.

div4.head: Northern version of affairs in New Mexico.
div4.p:
--Mr. Mitchell, a merchant of New Mexico, arrived in this city yesterday.
He confirms the report of the abandonment of Santa Fe by the rebels, who were retreating as fast as they could from the Territory.

They were destitute of all munitions and provisions, and there is no hope of their being supplied from any quarter.
At Santa Fe the rebels levied heavily on the merchants, in some cases taking as high as $15,000 worth of goods, paying for them in Confederate scrip.

It was believed that General Canby would now follow the rebels and drive them out of the Territory.
No doubt exists as to the ability of the United States troops to keep out he invaders, but an accession of two or three regiments of troops is necessary to keep the Apaches and Navajo in subjection.
They have been committing depredations for months past, stealing and mules and everything that came in their way.

The report of the formation of a Territorial Government under the rebel authority, has no foundation.
All the territorial officers had returned to Santa Fe and resumed the performance of their duties.
Chief Justice Benedict is on his way to the States, and there is to United States Judge now in the Territory.

div3.head: Later from Europe.
div3.p: --The steamer America has arrived with advices to the 20th ult.

div4.head: The War in America
div4.p: The London Times editorially expatiates on the importance of the struggle for New Orleans, and says that the occupation of that place by the Federals would be like a tourniquet tightened over the great artery of the Seceded States.

The London Morning Herald has a sarcestic editorial on the protracted continuance of the American struggle.
It sees no signs of exhaustion in the North or discouragement in the South, and believes that a speedy peace is hopeless.
The editor further says that the Government at Washington should be permitted to have one more chance, and if it fail the Great Powers should promptly interfere on behalf of the general well being of mankind.
That this has not been done before is owing to the generosity of England, as France was ready; but it is time England should cease to stand between her own people and the relief they need.

div4.head: Iron-Plated Sheet.
div4.p: Further experiments in armor-plating ships are engaging the attention of France and England.
The Austrian Government has sent two naval engineers to America to inspect the Monitor and Merrimac and new coast fortification.

div4.head: France.
div4.p: It is rumored that the French police have arrested twelve hundred workmen on the charge of sedition.

div4.head: The latest.
div4.p: --Saxony has acceded to the French and Prussian commercial treaty.

div4.head: Russia.
div4.p:
The Russian Minister of the Interior has made two imperial propositions--one for accelerating the liberation of the series, and the other for creating a system of Parliamentary representation.
The propositions have been referred to the Council of the empire.

div4.head: Spain.
div4.p:
Spain will not, as reported.
withdraw her troops from Mexico.
They will stay till the satisfaction demanded is obtained
Liverpool, April 19.--The ship Sir Watter Scott was totally burned off Flushing.

div4.head: Commercial intelligence
div4.p: --The market continues closed for cotton, but some 3,000 bales were sold at firm prices.

Flour has an upward tendency.
Wheat is still advancing.
Sales since Tuesday at laid.
advance. Corn is steady

div3.head: The reported advance of the enemy towards Wytheville.
div3.p: The Lynchburg Republican, of yesterday, contains a letter dated Dublin Depot. May 5th, a portion of which we copy:

I have been astonished at the excitement existing upon the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad along this point, in relation to the reports of the advance of the Yankees.
I visited Wytheville, where I learned that our forces were surprised at Rocky Gap, which is ten or fifteen miles the other side of Mercer Court House, and all retreated but two companies, who fought the enemy 6 or 8 hours, when both sides beat a retreat.
Our loss was one killed and eight wounded.

Colonel Jenifer came back and alarmed the people of Wytheville and Dublin, reporting the Yankees advancing in large force, having before he left ordered the town of Princeton (Mercer C. H.) to be burnt, and all our stores, which was done; and it is reported that some muskets were destroyed, though it is believed the citizens saved the guns.
Col. Jenifer advised the Bank officers to move their specie from Wytheville, and every one was frightened until Col. Wharton had sc sent out, and ascertained that they were not advancing, and if they were, there were but few of them.

One of the officers from this place sent down after Col. Jenifer, and satisfied himself and our people that no Yankee force was near us, but that our forces now here and at Wytheville are completely without a head.
From the best information we can get, there are only two skeleton Yankee regiments with in 50 miles of this place.
Salt is selling in Forsyth, Ga., at $40 per sack.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 110, page 3.

div3.head: War news
div3.p:
We are without any special information with regard to the position of affairs in the last week.
The engagement of Saturday last and to the belief that a general and severe battle was about to occur between the Confederate and Federal forces, and the public and has since Sunday been in a feverish of anxiety for intelligence from that . The admirable and patriotic address Beauregard to the veterans of Elkhorn , in which he expresses the fullest confidence in their ability and strength to drive away the invaders of the sacred soil of the South, and reassured the people, and they confidently the impending struggle to result in a triumph for our arms, and a com and disastrous defeat to the mercenary ings who have no higher appreciation of arty and independence than a blind and devotion to a flag which is but the symbol of tyranny.

before Corinth, and their grand for the subjugation of the South will has received a blow from which their ex Generals will scarcely be able to themselves.
We can scarcely con the possibility of the defeat of Beauregard, who has been the successful General of the war.
Since writing the above, we have received through a special dispatch to the Enquirer, of following news from Corinth:

Corinth. May 5th--Everything remained yesterday.
It rained all day, and continues to rain this morning.
The enemy have been back from Farmington, according to appearances, for a day or two.

courier from Col. Scott's Louisiana cavalry arrived here last night.
He reports that the enemy, in evacuating Decatur, battered the pillars and burnt the bridges, Col. it crossed the river on the 3d and attacked several hundred Federals next day at , in Tennessee.
The Alabama road who captured, with all the enemy's tents and , and a number of wagons and arms with a loss on our side of only one.-- Captain Fendon, with a cannon.
proceeded if the next station on Indian creek.
The for Nashville, with General Mitchell, passed up the road half an hour previous.
ring the down train coming, laden with Federal supplies, logs were put on the track, produced a smash up, killing numbers of Federal troops.
The locomotive was also destroyed.
While returning, our troops were by the enemy's cavalry.

At Elk river, last Friday, a skirmish ensued, in which the enemy lost twelve.
Their Colonel was mortally wounded.
Our loss was two.
From the Peninsula our information is almost as imperfect and incomplete as that from the Southwest.
An official letter from Williamsburg states that the enemy pursued cavalry pickets nearly to the town Sunday afternoon, but were easily repulsed by the rear guard, commanded by Brig. Gen. The enemy lost a piece of artillery, two and some fifteen prisoners. The Virginia cavalry, Lieut.-Col. Wickham, made a handsome charge.
Beyond this, we have nothing but rumors, which are hardly worth consideration.
An absurd story has been it circulation for the past day or two that on Sunday one or two regiments of our rear guard were captured by the enemy.
We believe the rumor is entirely groundless, and suppose it to have originated in some distempered imagination, or in the brain of some cowardly miscreant, who sees a "ghost in every fence corner."

Our information from the Valley of Virginia represents the armies of Jackson and well as in fine condition and excellent spirits, and anxious to be led against the invaders.
We deem it prudent to withhold such information as we have in reference to the position and strength of these forces, but believe them to be ample for the emergency.
An official dispatch from Staunton, dated 5th instant, states that the enemy evacuated Harrisonburg on Monday.
The town is now in possession of our Cavalry.
Under Captain Winfield.
We are rather sorry than otherwise to hear of this retirement of the Federal forces.
We wanted them to receive a severe thrashing, which we are satisfied would have been inflicted upon them if they had remained.
We hope yet that Gen. Jackson may overtake them before they leave the Valley.

div3.head: Purchase of cotton on foreign account.
div3.p: We append below a letter just addressed by the Department of State in answer to an inquiry by a Southern firm whether cotton purchased on foreign account would be treated as exempted from the general law which declares that all cotton shall be destroyed when it is about to fall into the hands of the enemy:

dateline.name:
Confederate States of America,
Department of State, Richmond,

div4.p: M ffis----
Ge I have your letter of 30th ult., it relation to purchases of cotton for persons residing in foreign countries.

I know no law which prohibits the purchase of cotton on foreign account, but I am not aware of any law or reason of policy which should induce this Government to extend to property thus purchased greater protection than is extended to that of our own citizens.
It is the settled determination of the Government to allow no cotton to fall into the hands of our enemies, as it is perfectly well known that they would seize and appropriate to themselves all cotton they could find, without regard to ownership.
If your correspondents buy cotton, they must expect to share the same risks as are in urred by our own citizens.
div4.closer:
Your obedient servant, J. P. Benjamin,
Sec'y of State.

div3.head: The enemy in Middlesex.
div3.p: From the subjoined letter, which appeared in yesterday's Whig, it seems that the invaders are pursuing their usual system of robbery and outrage among the defenceless inhabitants in the vicinity of the Rappahannock river:

Woodstock, Middlesex Co., May 2d. On Sunday last, about 3 o'clock, four row boats, with thirty-two Yankees, came up the Prankatank river, stopping at several places, and reached Mr. Thomas South's, on the Gloucester side, opposite my house.
So soon as they landed they ran up to the house, where they found no person but a negro woman.
Of her they demanded the keys.
She told them her mistress was out visiting, and had carried away the keys.
They immediately commenced breaking open the locks, and took all the meat from the meat house, and killed and carried away two hogs they found in a pen, carried away a boat, sail, and some bed clothing and wearing apparel.
On Tuesday they came up again in a large steamer and tug. The large steamer stopped at Freeport, and the tug went nearly to Turk's Ferry, where they went ashore, and one of the men stole a piece of meat from one of Dr. Nicolson's negro women.
They went down again in the afternoon, and about two and a half miles below my house they were fired on by artillery from Matthews.
One of the steamers was struck three times.
and the other twice.
Two of our men were slightly wounded.
After being fired on, they continued on out of the river, and I believe have not been in since.
Prior to that, their vessels for several days had been laying in Fishing Bay, about opposite to Sandy Bottom.
The Prankatank at my house is about three eighths of a mile wide. R. H.

div3.head: Nineteenth Virginia Regiment.
div3.p: The following are the staff officers elected by the 19th Virginia Regiment, Longstreet's Division, now on the Peninsula: John B. Strange, Colonel; Henry Gantt, Lieutenant, Colonel; John T. Ellis, Major.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Provost Marshal,
May 6, 1862.
special order, no.--.
div3.p: Messrs. Goddin & Apperson will turn over to Messrs. Clopton & Lyne, Agents of A. McKesver, the proceeds from the sale of his property, placed in their hands for the purpose of redeeming his individual notes.

By order.
E. Griswold,

Maj. and Prov.
Marshal.
E. A. Simple, Lieut. and Adj't.
Notice.

All persons holding any of my notes are hereby notified that agreeable to the above order the same will be redeemed by Messrs. Clopton & Lyne at as early a day as possible, and due notice will be given of the day on which they may be presented.

div3.head: Receiving stolen goods.
div3.p:
--A man named Geo. W. Cassiday, lately employed in some minor capacity at one of the military camps near this city, was arrested and brought before the Mayor yesterday, charged with having in his house, near the end of 2d street, a lot of boots, shoes, trunks, shoe- thread, pistols and other property belonging to; and stolen from, John Does and others.
The defendant not being able to account satisfactorily for the possession of the articles, was committed to jail to be examined before the justices of the Hustings Court on the 12th of May, for felony.

It has been deemed advisable, in case a necessity should arise for the destruction of the manufactured tobacco now stored in this city, that it should all be gathered together in certain prescribed warehouses, so that its destruction might certainly be assured if we are ever so unlucky as to have a visit from the Yankee vandals.
When this course was determined on, all owners were notified that they could remove their tobacco from the city, but would not be permitted to spread it about in small lots for the purpose of retaining it here and evading the order respecting it. Yesterday, Assistant Provost Marshal Alexander caused a lot of it to be seized which was being distributed in the wrong way.

div3.head: Police affairs.
div3.p:
--Among the arrests by the civil police yesterday, was Nancy Fortune, a free negro who was found sleeping in a porch, and in possession of $366, which it is thought she did not come honestly by.--Mary Swan, another female, being found drunk and not having a certificate of her freedom, was also locked up. She had in her possession a watch.
Wm. Miles and Samuel Lindsay, two white men, were caged for indulging in a hostile encounter on Main street.

div3.head: Fifty Sixth Regiment Virginia Volunteers.
div3.p:
--This fine regiment, pursuant to law, reorganized a few days since at Camp Fulton, near Richmond.
The following field and company officers were elected on that occasion, the new appointees being indicated by asterisks:
William D. Stuart, Colonel; P. P. Slaughter, Lt. Colonel; W. E. Green, Major.
Co. "A."--J. B. McPhail, Captain; F. W. Nelson, 1st L., J. A. Garner, 2d Lt.; A. D. Deggett, 3d Lt.
Co. "B."--T. J. Morton, Captain; J. W. Jones, 1st Lt; J. H. Moore, 2d Lt.; R. M. Horner, 3d Lt.
Co. "C."--Tim Smith, Captain; R. S. Eilis, 1st Lt., J. H. Smith, 2d Lt., J. F. Bibb, 3d Lt.
Co. "D."--J. P. Jones. Capt.; Mat. Brown, 1st Lt., J. Rudicill, 2d Lt; W. E. Jones, 3d Lt.
Co. "E."--B. C. Jones, Captain, J. A. Frayser, 1st Lt; J. T. Burton, 2d Lt.; W. A. Blick, 3d Lt.
Co. "F."--John Richardson, Captain; R. N. Thomas, 1st Lt.; W. H. Talley. 2d Lt.; W. J. Walton. 3d Lt.

Co. "G."--Thos. D. Jeffress, Captain.
John T. Chaffin, 1st Lt; Edward L. Haskins, 2d Lt.; F. C. Barnes, 3d Lt.
Co. "H."--J. C. Wyant, Captain; H. C. Michie. 1st Lt. J. S. Richards, 2d Lt; J. A. Miller, 3d Lt.
Co. "L."--W. W. Williams, Captain; C. J. Clark, 1st Lt; E. S. Clark, 2d Lt; Stephen D. Cronin, 3d Lt.

Co. "K." --James H. Mason.
Captain:--Williamson, 1st Lt. Edmund Tonjon, 2d Lt, W. E. Talley, 3d Lt.
This regiment was attached to "Floyd's Brigade" while in Kentucky and Tennessee, and won unfading laurels during the memorable four days struggle at "Donelson."

The Ladies' Bazaar, on Broad street, conducted by Mrs. Vernon, begins to present quite a busy appearance, and articles are being daily added to the already beautiful collection.
Several paintings and engravings, some of them very valuable, have recently been presented to the Association, and these, together with other things which adorn the bazaar, make it well worth a visit.
As is well known, the original purpose of the association was to expend the money collected and the proceeds of the sales to the building of a gunboat for the defence of Richmond.
Considering the number of sick soldiers now in the city, and the exertions of the Government in perfecting the defences of the river, it is proposed that the fund of the association be appropriated for the relief of sick and wounded soldiers.
It is to be hoped that the association may make this disposition of the money, as much more good could be accomplished with it. There are hundreds of sick soldiers now in the city who need relief and aid.

div3.head: Relief for the sick soldiers
div3.p:
--A meeting of the "Ladies Soldiers' Aid Society" will be held at the usual place on Thursday morning, at 11 o'clock. The members are requested to attend punctually, to make arrangements for attending to the sick soldiers in and around the city.
This is a noble mission, and every lady who embarks in it will receive her reward in the consciousness of having performed a deed of kindness and mercy.

The Current price of butter in the Richmond markets is now $1 per pound, an excess over California rates in the "flush times" of that auriferous region.
Under the supposition that demand is governed by supply, we presume the price is all right, but it is "digging," nevertheless.

div3.head: An example to Rock Throwers.
div3.p:
--Two small white lads were taken in custody yesterday, on Franklin street, by the Provost Marshal's guard, for throwing rocks at houses.
They were kept locked up for several hours and finally released after receiving an admonition on the enormity of their offence against decency.

A member of the 44th regiment of Pennsylvania, captured somewhere in the Valley, was brought to this city yesterday on the Central cars and lodged in the C. S. Military Prison.
None of the fifteen Yankees said to have been captured near Yorktown a few days since have yet been brought here.

div3.head: Matinee.
div3.p:
--To-day, at 11 o'clock, a grand Matinee comes off at Metropolitan Hall, at which time Lee Mallory's "War Illustrations" are exhibited.
At night, the entertainment is preceded by an interesting lecture on the forts and fortifications in and about New Orleans, with some accounts of men and things not generally known.
This is a double attraction

div3.head: Patriotic Contribution.
div3.p: --The members of the Sycamore (Disciples) church contributed on Sunday last $94 for the relief of our valiant soldiers who are sick at Camp Winder.

div3.head: Latest from Corinth.
div3.p:
--The Corinth correspondent of the Savannah Republican, of the 5th, says the roads are in shocking condition from the heavy rains, but it will be impossible to postpone a general engagement.
The enemy is making a movement on our right, supposed to be intended against the Mobile road.--Arrangements have been made to meet him.

Capt. Morgan has defeated and taken prisoners 80 Federals at Pulatoski, Tennessee.
He also captured a train loaded with Federal property.

div3.head: Latest from New Orleans.
div3.p:
--The Jackson Mississippian, of the 1st inst., has extracts from New Orleans papers of Tuesday.
The authorities of the city held out to the last in stubborn and heroic refusal to lower the flag of their adoption.

All the guns of Fort Jackson were spiked before the surrender.
Fort Pike was evacuated, and everything it contained abandoned.

Com. Farragut sent a communication to the Mayor and Council on the 28th ult., complaining of the refusal to haul down the Confederate flag, &c, and notified them to remove the women and children in forty-eight hours.
The Mayor convened the Council, and they decided not to recede from their position.
The Louisiana flag still floats upon the breeze.
Mayor Monroe nobly replied to Farragut, saying, "We will stand your bombardment, unarmed and undefended as we are."

Farragut, on the 29th, again addressed the Mayor, saying: "Forts Jackson and St. Philip have fallen, and we will now proceed to raise the United States flag on the Custom-House.
The Mayor must see that it is respected with all the civil power of the city. "

The evening Delta, of Wednesday, says that all the Confederate flags in the city have been lowered, and that Federal flags now float from the public buildings, under the protection of the enemy's guns.

All the city papers are still published, but are confined to local topics.
The Federals expect to take military possession of the city on Wednesday.

The Commandant of the French steamer, Milan, opposite New Orleans, notified Farragut that forty-eight hours notice of bombardment was ridiculous, and demanded sixty days for the evacuation of the city.

div4.p: On the 25th of April, by the Rev. Joshua Peterkin, Gen. Thomas S. Raymond, of Marion, and Lydia McCONNELL, of this city.
On the 5th inst., at the bride's residence, by the Rev. C. C. Pearson, Mr. Louis C. Le Grande, of Louisiana, to Miss Mildred S. Bowden, of Richmond, Va.
On the 1st inst., in this city, by the Rev. Mr. Brown, Major Graves and Miss Sarah E. Stockdale, all of this city.
Charlottesville and Petersburg papers please copy.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, on the 19th ultimo, in King William county, at the residence of the her husband, Mrs. Eliza R. Clements, wife of Young J. Clements, in the 60th year of her age.

For many years the victim of disease and intru e pain, she bore her sufferings with the utmost fortitude and resignation.
The sudden and unexpicted death in the army, in Richmond, of an affectionate and devoted son, just ten days previous to her own decease, had produced a shock too great for her enfeebled and wasted frame to bear.
Paralyzed by the blow, she sank rapidly but calmly, and earnestly desiring that peace and deliverance from bodily and mental suffering which she hopefully anticipated in death.
Possessed of an intelligent mind, distinguished for great candor and frankness of character, kind, social and affectionate in an exalted degree, she was surrounded by a large circle of relatives and friends, who deeply lamented the loss they have sustained.
Charity in an enlarged sense, benevolence and hospitality, were marked traits in her character; and in all the relations of life she was exemplary and blameless, and beloved by all who knew her. She has left a devoted husband and children, and near relatives, who watched over her, and did all in their power to soothe her dying pillow, and who have to mourn a loss which to them is irreparable; but they mourn not without hope that their loss is her gain. *

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.
div3.p: --I have received the requisite authority to enlist a corps of Partisan Rangers to serve during the war.

The corps is designed to consist of Mounted Riflemen, Cavalry, and Infantry, and have attached to it a company armed with the light howitzer.
I propose to operate within the enemy's lines, and will be enabled to hold out the prospect of a more active life than that which fails to the lot of the regular soldier; at all events, the members of the corps will not be subjected to the tedium of camp life.

I cordially and most earnestly invite all who desire to enter the Partisan branch of the service to unite with me, and all companies and battalions not mustered into the Confederate service.
I desire gentlemen who propose to unite with me to bring with them such private arms as they may be able to command — shot guns, rifles, pistols, &c.

The wolf is hunted for his scalp, and our Government has determined to pay for all arms and munitions of war which we may capture from the enemy; thus placing the invaders of our country and the oppressors of our liberty upon the footing of the savage beasts of the forest, to be captured or slain at all times and by any means not prohibited by legal warfare.

I invoke all enterprising men to join me, who are not engaged in the military service, and especially those whose homes are in the possession of the enemy — I invoke them to join me whether animated by a simple love of country, or a hatred of the public enemy; whether they have a wrong to redress, a vengeance to slake, or a home to protect.
Gentlemen wishing to raise companies for the corps will address me at Richmond city, Va, or apply in person at my recruiting rendezvous, in this city.
div3.closer:
John Scott,
my 7--ts Of Fauquier Capt. C. S. A.

div3.head:
Maryland E
District Columbia soldiers,
once more to the field.
div3.p:
Captain Edmund Barey is organizing a company to assist in repulsing the despoilers of our homes.
The well known military and civic antecedents of the commander will elicit the association of those to whom he is known.-- Exiles, shall we revisit the circles of our vacant families or live to wander and doubt?
Rendezvous on 10th, between Main and Bank streets.

div3.head:
Notice.--
attention!
Jefferson Guard.
div3.p:
Attend a meeting of your Company this evening, at 8 o'clock, at the Old Market Hall.
I hope every member of the Company will be present.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. Deusberry.
my 7--1t* Wm. B. Davis, O. S.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All young men between the ages of 16 and 18, who reside west of 14th street, north of James river, and one mile beyond the corporation line, will meet on the Capitol Square to- night, at 8 o'clock.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. Figner.
my 7--1t* L. B. Tatum, O. S.

div3.head: Reward.
div3.p:
--A reward of $80 will be paid for the recovery of my servant boy, Taylor, who left my house about the 19th of April. He was seen to get on board of the York River Railroad cars, in company with some soldiers on their way to Yorktown, who were supposed to belong to Gen. Longstreet's division.
Taylor is about 14 years old, rather small for his age, of dark ginger-break color, ready and smart in his address, and very sprightly in manner.
Address.
Francis W. Hancock,
Chief Surgeon 3d Division, or
Dr. Jas. E. Williams,
my 7--eod5t Richmond, Va.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my house, on the 5th inst., my negro boy, Joe. He is 5 feet 4 inches high, ginger-bread color, and a butcher by trade.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me, at my house, or my stall at the Old Market.
my 7--6t* Joseph Kirsh.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 110, page 4.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
May Festival to the country — patriotic action of the Ladies.
div3.p: As this is the day on which "Flowery" May of '62 makes its advent into the circle of Time, we presume it not improper to give you a few items by the "wayside. " of what has employed the attention of the good people in and around this "faith" little village during the day.

Much preparation had been made by the many fair maidens and kind mothers in and around this vicinity to celebrate with becoming splendor and g yety this historic day. --Tender hands had been busily engaged for several days in completing all preparations.
Ingenuity and genius had been at work to decorate all things with the most fastidious tested.
In fine, for some days the place has been distinguished for busy, busling, and constant stir.
The day arrived, and, notwithstanding the lowering clouds hung like stubborn sentinels in the way of the already established programme, and the frequent fall of partial showers, at an early hour the old church, long since dedicated to the cause of holiness and piety, was alive with human souls.

In the forenoon of the day, the care of the ladies was directed to the "minutia" of the fair, acting the part (and well did they perform it) of sales ladies — disposing of at the his best figures attainable all of the numerous trinkets and luscious delicacies most palatable to the epicure — the production of their own hands, which had been collected together.
Their gayly attired persons, lovely faces and bewitching words, made their appeals irresistible, and with a profess and liberal hand the multitude sided their efforts.
Soon the hour of 12 arrived — a table groaning under the weight of deticacles and substantial of every character, and description was spread out before the well-whetted appetites of the assemblage, and ample justice was rendered to the board.

The evening was occupied in the performance of most magnificent and brilliant tableson.
Some hours were consumed, during which time the audience was held in spell bound attention to the splendid, life-like exhibition.
A number of interesting plays were performed, and all in the most accomplished and attractive manner and style.
White the purpose and object of the whole proceedings was the most pure, noble and excited, the performance would have done honor to veteran stage active, and all who participated are assuredly entitled to praise for their complete success — White the "Seceding States" was the most grand and brilliant, "Hard Times" laughable also natural, the coronation of the Queen was in the highest degree solemn and imposing.

The income of the whole affair amounts to the respectable sum of $300, all of which will be appropriated for the relief of our wounded soldiers.
Ajaye.

div3.head: A missionary's Trials in China.
div3.p:
The subjoined extract is from a letter written by the Rev. Mr. Roberts, a Missionary among the Taspings in China.
It would seem that the Yankees, in their mode of conducting the war, are trying to imitate the barbarians of the East:

From having been the religious teacher of Rang-Sow-Chuch, in 1847, and hoping that good — religious, commercial, and political — would result to the nation from his elevation, I have hitherto been a friend to his revolutionary movement, sustaining it by word and deed, as far as a missionary consistently could without vitiating bit higher character as an ambassador of Christ.
But after living among them fifteen months, and closely observing their proceedings — political, commercial, and religions — I have turned over entirely a new leaf, and am now as much opposed to them, for good reasons.
I think, as I ever was in favor of them.
Not that I have sought personally against Hang-Sow-Chuen; he has been exceedingly kind to me. But I believe him to be a crazy men, entirely unfit to rule without any organized Government; not is he, with his Coolie Kings, capable of organizing a Government of equal benefit to the people with even the old imperial Government.
He is violent in his temper, and lets his wrath fall heavily upon his people, making a man or woman 'an offender for a word,' and ordering such instantly to be murdered, without 'judge or jury.' He is opposed to commerce, having had more than a dozen of his own people murdered since I have been here for no other crime than trading in the city, and has promptly repelled every foreign effort to establish lawful commerce among them, whether inside of the city or not. His religions toleration, and multiplicity of chapels, turn out to be a farce — of in the spread of Christianity — worse than useless.
It only amounts to a machinery for the promotion and spread of his own political religion, making himself equal with Jesus Christ, who, with God the Father, himself and his own son, constitutes one Lord over all Nor is any missionary who will not believe in his Divine appointment to this high equality, and promulgate his political religion accordingly, safe among the rebels in life, servants or property.
He told me soon after I arrived that if I did not believe in him I should perish, like the Jews.
for not believing in the Saviour.
But little did I then think that I should ever come so near it by the sword of one of his own miscreants, in his own capital, as I did the other day. Ean Wang, moved by his Coolie elder brother (literally a Coolie at Hong Kong) and the devil, without fear of God before his eyes, did, on Monday, the 13th inst., come into the house in which I was living, and then and there most willfully, m icicusly and with malice aforethought, murder one of my servants with a large sword in his own hand in my presence without a moment's warning or any just cause.
And after having slain my poor harmless, helpless he jumped on his head most fiendishly and stamped it with his foot, notwithstanding I besought him most entreatingly from the commencement of his murderous attack to spare my poor boy's life.
And not only so, but he insulted me myself in every possible way he could think of, to provoke me to do or any something which would give him an apology, as I then thought, and think yet, to kill me, as well as my dear boy, whom I loved like a son. He stormed at me, seized the bench on which I sat with the violence of a madman, threw the dregs of a cup of tea in my face; seized hold of me personally and shook me violently; struck me on my right cheek with his open hand.
Then, according to the instruction of my King, for whom I am ambassador, I turned the other, and he struck me quite a sounder blow on my left cheek with his right-hand, making my earing again; and then, perceiving that he could not provoke me to offend him in worn or deed, he seemed to get the more outrageous, and stormed at me like a dog to be gone out of his presence. 'If they will do these things in a green tree, what will they do in the dry?'--if to a favorite of Teen Wangis, who can trust himself among them, either as a missionary or a merchant?
I then despaired of missionary success among them, or any good coming out of the movement — religions, commercial, or political — and determined to leave them, which I did on Monday, January 20, 1862.

div3.head: Our present duty.
div3.p: --We take the following extract from a late editorial in the Charleston Courier:

q.p: We have had to bear servere trials, but they have not yet been as great as we feared they would be. We are now enduring many privations and evils, but our strength is equal to the suffering, and we are prepared and willing to pass through furnaces heated seven times hotter than any whose fires have yet burned around us, if at last we attain our high purpose.

We must not; we dare not, doubt of the eventual success.
Double at such a time as this is failure, failure is subjugation, subjugation is slavery, the most grinding and disgraceful thraldom that ever wrung the soul of freedom.
No! we dare not, do not doubt of final, complete and glorious success.
We contend for rights God has given us; for blessings, without which life were without value or interest; for the virtue of our wives and the chastity of our daughters.
We should address ourselves with fresh spirit and redoubled energy to this great work.
It demands all our talents, all our energies, all our valor, all our fortitude.
We must give ourselves to this vast undertaking, and cause from seeking our own pleasure, profit, ease and ambition.
And if faithful to our holy cause, if we suffer nobly, fight courageously, and perform all our high duties in the fear of God, as sure as there is a sun, we shall triumph over our foes, and stand before the nations an independent power.

div3.p: A single transgression of the law of God breaks a link in the chain which connects us with him, and sets us adrift on the stream of destruction.
Never did school text contain a more assured truth than that which records "Idleness is the parent of vice" and of idleness, the worst is idleness of mind.
Habit in a child is at first like a spider's web — if neglected, it becomes a thread or a twine; next a cord or rope; finally a cable; and then who can break it?
The great God seems to have given that commandment — know thyself — to those men more especially who are apt to make remarks on other men's actions, and forget themselves.
It is a very good lesson, though it is learned with difficulty, and rarely practiced — to love those that hate us.
If we did but know how little some enjoy the great things they possess, there would not be much envy in the world.
Conceit and confidence are both of them cheated: the first always imposes upon itself, the second frequently deceives others too.
He who marries a pretty face only, is like a buyer of cheap furniture — the velnish that caught the eye cannot endure the fireside blaze.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adr't and Insp, Gen.'s office,
Richmond; May 3d, 1862.
General Orders--no. 84.
div3.p: 1. The following proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:

div4.head: Proclamation.
div4.p: By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus:

I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the counties of Lee, Wise, Buchanan, McDowell, and Wyoming, under the command of Brigadier-General Humphrey Marshall; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probe to of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus in the counties aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto argued my name, and set my seal this the 3d day of May, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.

II. Brigadier-General Humphrey Marshall is charged with the due execution of the foregoing proclamation.
He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders:

All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forth with be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibitions will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial: provided, that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th article of war.
div4.closer: By command of the Secretary of War. S. Cooper. my 5--6t Adj't and Insp. Gen'l.

div3.head: Attention, Marylanders!
div3.p: The following copy of a letter from Hon. Geo. W. Randolph, Secretary of War, sets at rest all doubts as to the position of Marylanders under the Conscription Act:

div4.head: [copy.]

opener.dateline:
Confederate States of America.
War Department,
Richmond, May 1, 1862. Capt. R. C. smith, Co. "C," 1st Maryland Reg't, Care Major J. A. Waston, Richmond, Va.:

div4.p: In reply to your letter of the 22d ult., you are respectfully informed that the Maryland companies are not subject to conscription, and will go out of service when their term of enlistment expires.
div4.closer: Your obedient servant, Geo. W. Randolph, Secretary of War.

div4.p: This applies to all Marylanders, as shown by the following extract from another letter from the Secretary of War, dated April 26th.
"Major J. A. Weston:
"In reply to your letter of the 17th inst., you are respectfully informed that Marylanders are not subject to the Conscription Act.
div4.closer: "G. W. Randolph, "Secretary of War."By this decision all twelve months Marylanders who have been re-enlisted under compulsion are entitled to their discharge or transfer, and all who have re-enlisted voluntarily have still the privilege of electing the company or regiment which they will join. my 5--6t*

div3.p:
Deserted — On the 26th inst., from the camp of the 19th regiment Virginia Volunteers, one Robert Byrnes, a private of Company K, same regiment.
Said Byrnes was accepted as a substitute on the 25th inst.; says that he was born in Ireland, but has more the appearance of an English sailor; is about 5 feet 11½ inches high, dark complexion, gray eyes, dark hair, and about 27 years old; has a considerable scar on the left side of his neck.
All officers, civic and military, are earnestly requested to use every exertion to arrest this man. He is no doubt lurking about Richmond, probably endeavoring to hire himself again as a substitute — The usual reward will be paid upon his delivery to me here, or if he is lodged in any jail where I can get him.
div3.closer: Matthew Lyle, Capt. commd'g Co. K. 18th Va. Reg't.P. S.--Byrres had with him naturalization papers of a very recent date; given him in Richmond. M. L. my 8--tw

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $50 reward for the arrest and delivery to Capt. Alexander, Assistant Provost Marshal, at Richmond, of each of the following described persons, who have deserted from my company.
Gainea's Station, Caroline county, Va., viz:
Henry Carpenter, aged 19 years, 5 feet 6½ inches high, has black hair; hazel eyes complexion; full face, small chin, projecting feets, and has the left thumb.
M. G. Hoxter, aged 21 years, about 5 feet 9 inches high, has brown hair, blue eyes, ruddy complexion, and is broad-shouldered and squarely built.
Wallace Wilson, is aged 19 years, about 5 feet 8 inches high, has dark hair, dark complexion, and is splendidly built.
George Ceeley, aged 23 years, 6 feet 1½ inches high, has brown hair, hazel eyes, slight moustache, and round features.
Augustus Rueketts, is aged 18 years, 5 feet 7 ½ inches high, has light brown hair, hazel eyes, fair complexion, and is slightly made.
Jno. Wm. Doll, is aged 20 years, 5 feet 8½ inches high, has black hair, hazel eyes, ruddy complexion, full, round face, and was raised in Henrico county.
All of the above named deserters are believed to be in Richmond at this time.
div3.closer: Greenlee Davidson, my 3--1w* Capt. Letcher Artillery.

div3.p: The following men having deserted from the 56th Virginia Regiment, the usual reward of $30 is hereby offered for their apprehension and delivery:
Company A, Capt. Boswell.--Robert Puryear, A. D. Brommell
Company C, Capt. Smith.--Jos Atnett, M B Sims, Elijah Hester, Thomas Mills, A J Bibb.
Company D, Capt. Patterson.--William R Brown.
Company F, Capt. Richardson.--William Perry.
Company H, Capt. Michie.--Elias Morris, Dennis Shiflet, Overton Shiflet, Linens Shiflet, Smith Shiflet, Jno Ballard.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Stuart, Col. Comd'g 56th Reg't Va. Vols.
my 1--6t* W. H. Otey, Adj't.

div3.head:
[extract]
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va.,April 30, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 18--

1. Paragraph II, General Orders No. 12, Head quarters Department of Henrico, March 31, 1862, establishing a tariff of maximum prices to be charged for produce, &c., sold in the markets of this city, is hereby revoked.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder
J. R. Page, ap 30--6t Assistant Adjutant-General.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 11, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 6.

list.item:
II.
Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.
Superintendents of railroads are requested to report daily to the Provost Marshall the number of passengers passing over their roads out of the city of Richmond.

div3.closer: By order of Brig. Gen'l Jno. H. Winder, Com. &c. mh 13--ts L. R. Page, A. A. Gen'l.

div3.head:
Headquarters Ordnance Departm't,
Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is Desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting State arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer: C. Dimmock, mh 29--tf Col. of Ordnance of Virginia.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Capt. Wm. W. Parker's Company of Light Artillery having been mustered into service, and secured a battery of six guns, are now in the camp of instruction, and will receive a few more Recruits, if they are of the right sort.
Apply at his office in the Law Building.
at once.
mh 12--ts

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.
div3.closer: A. B. Guigon, mh 23--ts Captain Light Artillery.

div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organise a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Peart street, or by mail to
div3.closer: J. A. Weston, mh 16--ts Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Bayly's Heavy Artillery.
div3.p:
--I will receive twenty more men to complete my battery of Heavy Artillery.
Apply at the office of Bayly & White, at the corner of Franklin and 12th streets, or at the rendezvous, at 109 Main st., (up stairs.)
div3.closer:
Samuel T. Bayly, Captain of Bayly's Artillery.
A. L. Rodgers, 1st Lieut.
Jos. A. Williams, 2d Lt. ap 30--6t*

div3.head: Attention, Volunteers.--Infantry Company--Scott's Battalion.
div3.p:
--Under authority from the Secretary of War, the undersigned--two of whom are graduates of the Virginia Military Institute--are forming an Infantry Company for the battalion now being raised by Robert G. Scott, who served as Captain of Virginia volunteers in the Mexican war. Men liable to service under the conscript act can volunteer in this company and receive the bounty, &c., instead of being enrolled as conscripts, as they soon will be, to fill up companies now in service, without receiving any bounty.
Men in companies for local service wishing to go into active service may also join the company.
Recruiting office 10th street, between Main and Bank.
div3.closer:
J. Wickham,
Wm. J. Eggleston,
Chas. Carter, ap 28--ts Arthur F. Gooch.

div3.head:
Second Company
Johnson's Light
Artillery.
div3.p:
More recruits are wanted for this company forthwith.
The conscription will soon be passed, mustering into the service every man in the Confederacy between the ages of 18 and 85, leaving no option with the conscript as to where he shall go, or to what arm of the service he shall belong.

All those who prefer to select the Light Artillery as their service should take at once the last opportunity they will probably have to volunteer.
We desire, at the earliest possible moment, to complete our organization and take the field, where all who are fit for service should be, and where they must be soon, either voluntarily or by compulsion.

Those who have been in service know that the Light Artillery is the most agreeable as well as the most effective arm of the service.
Come at once, then, while the chance is given you to enlist where you please, and relieve yourselves from the opprobrium of compulsory service.
Recruiting Office, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon,
James H. Hackett, ap 16--ts John H. Leetwich.

div3.p: I have been Authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of Heavy Artillery for three years, or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wants only a few companies requisite to its completion.
I should be glad to confer with captains who have companies, and also with those who desire to raise companies.

p.q: "Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection by a medical officer, to gather with transportation and subsistence from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered."

div3.p: Twelve months men can re-enlist singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty; and will also be transferred during the twenty days previous to the expiration of their present term.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies from any portion of the Confederacy.

Office--Tenth street, three doors from Main.
City Post-Office, Box 877.

div3.head: Attention, Martin's battery!
div3.p: --All members of this command who are absent without leave, will report at once at "Camp Lee," or they will be reported to the Provost Guard and arrested as deserters.
Persons wishing to join the company will apply to Serg't Pulliam, at the Recruiting office, corner of Bank and 12th streets.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p: --Several Chambermaids, and a plain Cook accomstomed to farm, Apply to B.A. Cocke. Office No. 4 Law Bulding
my6 — 2t Franklin street

div3.head: For sale.
div3.p:
--We have at private sale, to remain in this city, a valuable middle-aged Woman, an excellent Nurse, good Washer, and Ironer, and accostomed to general housework.
Apply at once to
my 5--3t* Dickinson, Hill & Co.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A good Cook, without encumbrance.
Apply at this office.
my 2ߞts

$10 reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to me of my negro boy Stump, sometimes called Lewis Worsham.
He left Chimborazo Hospital (where he was hired) about a week or ten days ago, and has since been seen about Camp Winder, trying to hire himself out. He is about 18 years of age; 4½ feet high; gingerbread color, and has had a sore leg; which may have left some scars.
my 2--1w* Samuel Hardgrove.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the Farish House, in Charlottesville, on Tuesday, the 22d day of April, a negro boy, named Buck, belonging to the estate of Wm. T. McCarty, dec'd. He left in company with three other boys belonging to Mr. C. Taylor, of Alexandria.
Buck is about 5 feet high, black, with a good suit of hair, and about 18 years of age. The above reward will be paid for his safe delivery in the county jail of Albemarle, or in Mr. Grady's jail, below the corner of 15th and Cary streets, Richmond, Va.
my 2--6.* Jas. B McCarty, Adm'r.

div3.head: $30 reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted from the First Maryland Regiment, George W. Bishop, formerly Sergeant Major of the Regiment.
Said Bishop is about five feet four inches high, twenty-two years of age, and quite fat. Is supposed to be lurking about North Carolina somewhere, pretending to be a Lieutenant.
The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to his regiment.
By order.
Lieut. Col. Johnson,
Com'd'g First Md. Reg't.

F. H. Ward, Adjutant.
my 1--6t*

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--A mulatto girl, named Emma, some four weeks since.
She is about 18 years old, is tolerably spare built and about 5 feet 1 or 2 inches high, and has tolerably good hair.
She was hired to James Abel, 17th street. We are willing to pay a liberal reward for her delivery to us, and forewarn all persons from harboring her.
Clopton & Lyne,
my 1--6t* Franklin street.

div3.head: Ranaway.--$20 to $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on 1st of Feb'y, my men George; 22 years old; black; round features; weighs about 160 pounds; 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high; erect; a hearse, quick manner of speech, and may be called good looking.
Having been raised by the late Wiley Bickinson, near Barboursville, he has been and will lurk in that region, or may have fallen in with our army in some manner — most likely as a cook — and now on the Peninsula, or gone towards the enemy.
If found in the army, or beyond Culpeper C. H., and delivered in jail not farther than Richmond, so that I got him again, I will give $50, otherwise, I will give the first sum.
S. W. Ficklin.
Charlottesville, April 24, 1862. ap 25--12t*

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--The subscribers will pay the above reward for the apprehension and delivery at the 15th Alabama regiment, or the jail in Richmond, of two negro Boys, who made their escape from the above named regiment, in the neighborhood of Rappahannock, about the 18th March, ult., and who are described as follows, viz: Jim, of light complexion, about 5 feet 10 inches high, stammers when spoken to, weighs about 180 pounds, and has a large scar on his forehead.
Charles, of dark complexion, about 6 feet high, slender of stature, and of about 165 pounds weight.
Captain P. V. Guerry,
Lieut. B. P. Head.
Rappahannock, Va., April 8, 1862,

div3.head: $25 reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thick set, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
S. S. Cotterell,
ap 2--ts No. 129 Main street.
